data.title: Asking for Trouble (1942)
data.meta_description: A London fishmonger helps a young woman evade her unwanted upcoming marriage by pretending to be her fiancé, a big game hunter from Africa. Comedy.
data.text:
Oswald Mitchell’s British comedy in which a British bookmaker (Max Miller) attempts to rescue a general’s (Mark Lester) daughter (Carol Lynne) from a big-game hunter. With Wilfrid Hyde-White.

The story concerns a London fishmonger who takes up bookmaking to make ends encounter, and also assists a young woman avoid her discarded upcoming marriage by posing to be her fiancé, a big game hunter from Africa.

Max Miller gives an okay performance in his role as Dick Smith, the bookmaker involved, while Carol Lynne is alright as Jane Smythe, the woman who finds herself in an awful situation.

Elsewhere, Mark Lester is reasonable as General Smythe, while Wilfrid Hyde-White as Pettifer, Billy Percy as George, Eleanor Hallam as Margarita, Aubrey Mallalieu…
